statements.name: PROC CPANEL
statements.description: The CPANEL procedure analyzes a class of linear econometric models that arise when time series and cross-sectional data are combined. This type of data is called panel data. Typical examples of panel data include observations over time on people, households, countries, or firms. For example, in the case of survey data on household income, the panel is created by repeatedly surveying the same households over many years. The individual entities that are followed over time are called cross sections.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Names the input data table for PROC CPANEL to use. The default is the most recently created data table. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where

arguments.name: NOPART
arguments.description: Prevents repartitioning of the data. Normally, the CPANEL procedure redistributes the data table so that observations for each cross section are not divided among multiple machines.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all printed output.

arguments.name: PRINTALL
arguments.description: Prints all available output.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: You can specify a BY statement in PROC CPANEL to obtain separate analyses of observations in groups that are defined by the values of the BY variables. If you specify more than one BY statement, only the last one specified is used.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement names the classification variables to be used as explanatory variables in the analysis.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Reverses the sort order of the classification variable. If both the DESCENDING and ORDER= options are specified, PROC BCHOICE orders the categories according to the ORDER= option and then reverses that order.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Treats missing values (., ._, .A, …, .Z for numeric variables and blanks for character variables) as valid values for the CLASS variable.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the sort order for the levels of classification variables. This ordering determines which parameters in the model correspond to each level in the data. By default, ORDER=FORMATTED. For ORDER=FORMATTED and ORDER=INTERNAL, the sort order is machine-dependent. When ORDER=FORMATTED is in effect for numeric variables for which you have supplied no explicit format, the levels are ordered by their internal values.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the external formatted value, except for numeric variables with no explicit format, which are sorted by their unformatted (internal) value.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the descending frequency count (levels that have more observations come ealier in the order).

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the unformatted value. The sort order is machine-dependent.

arguments.name: PARAM=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameterization method for the classification variable or variables.
arguments.help: PARAM=EFFECT | GLM | ORDINAL|THERMOMETER | POLYNOMIAL|POLY | REFERENCE|REF | ORTHEFFECT | ORTHORDINAL|ORTHOTHERM | ORTHPOLY | ORTHREF

arguments.name: EFFECT
arguments.description: Specifies effect coding.

arguments.name: GLM
arguments.description: Specifies less-than-full-rank, reference-cell coding; this option can be used only as a global option.

arguments.name: ORDINAL
arguments.description: Specifies the cumulative parameterization for an ordinal CLASS variable.

arguments.name: POLYNOMIAL
arguments.description: Specifies polynomial coding.

arguments.name: REFERENCE
arguments.description: Specifies reference-cell coding.

arguments.name: ORTHEFFECT
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=EFFECT.

arguments.name: ORTHORDINAL
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=ORDINAL.

arguments.name: ORTHPOLY
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=POLYNOMIAL.

arguments.name: ORTHREF
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=REFERENCE.

arguments.name: REFERENCE=
arguments.description: Specifies the reference level that is used when you specify a nonsingular parameterization.
Specifies the level of the variable to use as the reference level. Specify the formatted value of the variable if a format is assigned. Replace <level> with an actual value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Designates the first ordered level as reference.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Designates the last ordered level as reference.

statements.name: COMPARE
statements.description: The COMPARE statement creates tables of side-by-side comparisons of parameter estimates and other model statistics. You can fit multiple models simultaneously by specifying multiple MODEL statements, and you can specify a COMPARE statement to create tables that compare the models. The COMPARE statement creates two tables: the first table compares model fit statistics such as R-square and mean square error; the second table compares regression coefficients, their standard errors, and (optionally) t tests.

arguments.name: MSTAT=
arguments.description: Specifies a list of model fit statistics to be displayed. A set of statistics is displayed by default, but you can use this option to specify a custom set of model statistics. The mstat-list can contain one or more of the following keywords:
arguments.help: MSTAT=ALL | DFE | F | FNUMDF | FDENDF | M | MDF | MSE | NCS | NOBS | NONE | NTS | PROBF | PROBM | RMSE | RSQUARE | SSE | VARCS | VARERR | VARTS

arguments.name: OUTPARM=
arguments.description: Names an output data set to contain the data from the comparison table for parameter estimates, standard errors, and t tests. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where CAS-libref refers to the caslib and session identifier, and data-table specifies the name of the output data table.

arguments.name: OUTSTAT=
arguments.description: Names an output data set to contain the data from the comparison table for model fit statistics, such as R-square and mean square error. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where CAS-libref refers to the caslib and session identifier, and data-table specifies the name of the output data table.

arguments.name: PSTAT=
arguments.description: Specifies a list of parameter statistics to be displayed. By default, estimated regression coefficients and their standard errors are displayed. Use this option to specify a custom set of parameter statistics. pstat-list can contain one or more of the following keywords:
arguments.help: PSTAT=ALL | ESTIMATE | NONE | STDERR | PROBT | T

statements.name: CORRELATED
statements.description: The CORRELATED statement selects the subset of effects from the MODEL statement that are correlated with the individual (or cross-sectional) error term. This statement is valid only when you specify the AMACURDY or HTAYLOR model estimation method in the MODEL statement.

statements.name: ENDOGENOUS
statements.description: The ENDOGENOUS statement declares a set of effects that are treated as endogenous during estimation, and is valid only when performing either instrumental variables regression or dynamic panel estimation.

arguments.name: EQ=
arguments.description: Specifies which equations include the endogenous instruments.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Includes the endogenous instruments in both the difference and level equations.

arguments.name: DIFF
arguments.description: Includes the endogenous instruments only in the difference equations.

arguments.name: LEVEL
arguments.description: Includes the endogenous instruments only in the level equations.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement specifies variables in the input data set that identify the cross section and time period for each observation. Sometimes estimation does not require a time variable, in which case specifying the time-series-id variable is optional.

statements.name: INSTRUMENTS
statements.description: The INSTRUMENTS statement specifies instrumental variables and effects, and is valid only when performing either instrumental variables regression or dynamic panel estimation.

arguments.name: EQ=
arguments.description: Specifies which equations include the standard instruments.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Includes the standard instruments in both the difference and level equations.

arguments.name: DIFF
arguments.description: Includes the standard instruments only in the difference equations.

arguments.name: LEVEL
arguments.description: Includes the standard instruments only in the level equations.

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: The MODEL statement specifies the regression model, the error structure that is assumed for the regression residuals, and the estimation technique to be used. The response variable (response) on the left side of the equal sign is regressed on the independent variables (effects), which are listed after the equal sign. You can specify any number of MODEL statements. For each MODEL statement, you can specify only one response.

arguments.name: AMACURDY
arguments.description: Requests Amemiya-MaCurdy estimation for a model that has correlated individual (cross-sectional) effects. You specify the correlated effects by using the CORRELATED statement.

arguments.name: ARTESTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum order of the test for the presence of autoregression (AR) effects. By default, ARTESTS=2.

arguments.name: BIASCORRECTED
arguments.description: Computes the bias-corrected covariance matrix of the two-step generalized method of moments (GMM) estimator.

arguments.name: BTWNG
arguments.description: Estimates a between-groups model.

arguments.name: DLAGS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of dependent-variable lags to use as regressors. By default, DLAGS=1.

arguments.name: DYNDIFF
arguments.description: Estimates a dynamic panel by using the generalized method of moments (GMM) on equations that are formed by first differencing.

arguments.name: DYNSYS
arguments.description: Estimates a dynamic panel by using GMM on the system that combines first-differenced equations and level equations.

arguments.name: FDONE
arguments.description: Estimates a one-way model by using first-differenced methods.

arguments.name: FIXONE
arguments.description: Estimates a one-way fixed-effects model that corresponds to cross-sectional effects only.

arguments.name: FIXTWO
arguments.description: Estimates a two-way fixed-effects model.

arguments.name: GINV=
arguments.description: Specifies what type of generalized inverse to use.

arguments.name: G2
arguments.description: Uses the G2 generalized inverse.

arguments.name: G4
arguments.description: Uses the G4 generalized inverse.

arguments.name: GMM=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of GMM stages to use in the estimation.

arguments.name: ONESTEP
arguments.description: Uses one-step GMM, which is computationally simple but dependent on model assumptions.

arguments.name: TWOSTEP
arguments.description: Uses two-step GMM, which is computationally intensive but more robust to violations of model assumptions.

arguments.name: HTAYLOR
arguments.description: Requests Hausman-Taylor estimation for a model that has correlated individual (cross-sectional) effects. You specify the correlated effects by using the CORRELATED statement.

arguments.name: IBVTWNG
arguments.description: Requests instrumental variables between-groups estimation for a model that has endogenous effects. You specify the endogenous effects by using the ENDOGENOUS statement, and you specify external instruments by using the INSTRUMENTS statement.

arguments.name: IVFIXONE
arguments.description: Requests instrumental variables one-way fixed-effects estimation for a model that has endogenous effects. You specify the endogenous effects by using the ENDOGENOUS statement, and you specify external instruments by using the INSTRUMENTS statement.

arguments.name: IVPOOLED
arguments.description: Requests instrumental variables pooled regression. You specify the endogenous effects by using the ENDOGENOUS statement, and you specify external instruments by using the INSTRUMENTS statement.

arguments.name: IVRANONE
arguments.description: Requests instrumental variables one-way random-effects estimation for a model that has endogenous effects. You specify the endogenous effects by using the ENDOGENOUS statement, and you specify external instruments by using the INSTRUMENTS statement.

arguments.name: MAXBAND=
arguments.description: If specified, sets the maximum number of GMM-style instruments per observation, for each variable.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the intercept parameter from the model.

arguments.name: NOLABEL
arguments.description: suppresses variable labels from the printed output.

arguments.name: POOLED
arguments.description: Specifies a pooled (OLS) model.

arguments.name: PRINTFIXED
arguments.description: Estimates and prints the fixed effects in models where they would normally be absorbed within the estimation.

arguments.name: RANONE
arguments.description: Estimates a one-way random-effects model.

arguments.name: RANTWO
arguments.description: Estimates a two-way random-effects model.

arguments.name: ROBUST
arguments.description: Computes the robust covariance matrix of the generalized method of moments (GMM) estimator.

arguments.name: VCOMP=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of variance component estimate to use. By default, VCOMP=SA.

arguments.name: FB
arguments.description: Uses the Fuller-Battese method.

arguments.name: NL
arguments.description: Uses the Nerlove method.

arguments.name: SA
arguments.description: Uses the Swamy-Arora method.

arguments.name: WH
arguments.description: Uses the Wallace-Hussain method.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates a data table that contains observationwise statistics that PROC CPANEL computes after fitting the model. In order to avoid data duplication for large data tables, only the identification and dependent variables are included in the output data table unless you specify additional variables in the COPYVAR= option. To avoid further data duplication, the OUTPUT statement is allowed only with MODEL statements that request a single estimation. If you have multiple MODEL statements, then each OUTPUT statement is associated with the MODEL statement that immediately precedes it.

arguments.name: COPYVAR=
arguments.description: Transfers one or more variables from the input data set to the output data table.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data table for PROC CPANEL to use. You must specify this option before any other options. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where

arguments.name: PREDICTED=
arguments.description: Writes the predicted values to the output data set.

arguments.name: RESIDUAL=
arguments.description: Writes the residuals to the output data set.

statements.name: PREDETERMINED
statements.description: The PREDETERMINED statement specifies a set of variables whose instruments follow a prescribed form that is appropriate for predetermined regressors, and is valid only when you perform dynamic panel estimation by specifying the DYNDIFF or DYNSYS options in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: EQ=
arguments.description: Specifies which equations include the standard instruments.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Includes the predetermined instruments in both the difference and level equations.

arguments.name: DIFF
arguments.description: Includes the predetermined instruments only in the difference equations.

arguments.name: LEVEL
arguments.description: Includes the predetermined instruments only in the level equations.

statements.name: RESTRICT
statements.description: The RESTRICT statement specifies linear equality restrictions on the parameters in the previous MODEL statement. There can be as many unique restrictions as the number of parameters in the preceding MODEL statement. Multiple RESTRICT statements are understood as joint restrictions on a model’s parameters. Restrictions on the intercept are obtained by the use of the INTERCEPT keyword. RESTRICT statements before the first MODEL statement are automatically associated with the first MODEL statement, in addition to any RESTRICT statements that follow it but precede subsequent MODEL statements.

statements.name: TEST
statements.description: The TEST statement performs Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests of linear hypotheses about the regression parameters in the preceding MODEL statement. Like RESTRICT statements, TEST statements before the first MODEL statement are automatically associated with the first MODEL statement, in addition to any TEST statements that follow it but precede subsequent MODEL statements.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests.

arguments.name: LM
arguments.description: Requests the Lagrange multiplier test.

arguments.name: LR
arguments.description: Requests the likelihood ratio test.

arguments.name: WALD
arguments.description: Requests the Wald test.
